teamMembers.name: Austin Daniel

icp.title: The Growth-Obsessed Founder
icp.companyStage: Seed to Series C SaaS/tech startups (5-50 employees)

connectCriteria: Founding CEO or technical co-founder at early-stage SaaS
Posts about hiring engineers, building MVP, or scaling product
Raised seed/Series A in last 12 months
Mentions 'technical debt,' 'need to ship faster,' or 'team capacity'
Active in SaaStr, YC, or similar communities
engageCriteria: Posts general startup advice (not specific pain)
realQuotes: The building-as-procrastination trap is so real. I finally started doing customer calls when I made it a game.
I'd be a billionaire if my CTO and I could have gotten along better.
Behind every successful founder is paralyzing self-doubt, money issues, failed products.
The startup problem is fundamentally a search problem under resource constraint.
I realized most founders obsess over signups but ignore what happens in the first 3 minutes after login.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw your post about [specific challenge]. That's the exact problem we help founders solve at Midwestern. Curious—are you handling [specific task] internally or bringing in outside help?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: When they post about capacity/hiring challenges

conversationStarters.template: [Name], been following your journey with [company]. We work with a lot of founders at your stage (Series A, scaling eng team) and the 'need to ship vs. need to hire' tension is real. How are you thinking about that?

conversationStarters.whenToUse: Soft opener when relationship is warming up

contentPillars.title: Speed Wins Stories
examples: Case study: How [startup] shipped their MVP in 6 weeks instead of 6 months
Behind-the-scenes: What a scoped project actually looks like [screenshots]
Data point: The average cost of a 6-month hiring delay

contentPillars.title: Founder Realities
examples: Hot take: Stop hiring full-time engineers for MVP validation
Poll: What's slowing you down more: unclear requirements or team capacity?
Carousel: 5 signs you need embedded engineers, not full-time hires

contentPillars.title: Transparent Process
examples: Here's our exact scoping process [step by step]
What it looks like to integrate into a client's Slack
We lost a client because [lesson learned]

engagementBoosters: Post at 8am or 12pm CT when founders check LinkedIn with coffee/lunch
Start posts with hooks: 'Unpopular opinion:' or 'Hard truth:' or 'Quick story:'
End posts with questions to trigger comments
Comment on 5-10 founder posts BEFORE posting your own
Tag relevant people/communities when appropriate (not spammy)
redFlags: Non-technical founder with no CTO (needs recruiting first)
Focus on thought leadership, not building
trustBuilders: Team credentials (who are the actual developers?)

examplePosts.title: Speed Win Story
examplePosts.content:
We just helped a founder ship their MVP in 6 weeks instead of 6 months.

Here's what they cut:
• Admin dashboard (not needed at $0 ARR)
• User roles and permissions (launched single-user)
• Email notifications (Slack worked fine for now)
• Social login (email/password was enough)

The result? Shipped, validated with 10 customers, and raising a seed round.

Building gets easier. Deciding what NOT to build stays hard.

What would you cut from your MVP?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Contrarian timeframe (6 weeks vs 6 months) grabs attention. Specific, relatable cuts build credibility. Concrete outcome (raising seed) shows value. Question at end drives engagement.

examplePosts.title: Hiring Pain Point
examplePosts.content:
"We can't ship until we hire 3 more engineers."

I hear this from founders every week.

The math doesn't add up:
• 6-8 weeks to find candidates
• 3-4 weeks to close offers
• 2 weeks for them to give notice
• 2-4 weeks for onboarding

That's 4+ months before they ship a line of code.

Meanwhile your competitor just launched.

There's a better way: Embedded teams ship code on week 1.

Thoughts? Am I missing something here?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Universal pain point (slow hiring). Specific timeline breakdown. Implicit value prop without hard sell. Humble question keeps it conversational.

examplePosts.title: Hot Take for Engagement
examplePosts.content:
Unpopular opinion: Most startups over-engineer their MVPs.

You don't need:
❌ A design system (a few Tailwind classes work fine)
❌ Automated testing (manual QA is faster for MVP)
❌ Microservices (a monolith ships faster)
❌ Perfect error handling (console.log is enough)

You DO need:
✅ Something customers can use today
✅ A way to collect feedback
✅ The ability to change it tomorrow

"Tech debt" doesn't matter if you never get customers.

Change my mind.
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Controversial opinion drives debate in comments. Clear structure (don't vs do). 'Change my mind' explicitly invites disagreement. Pure engagement play.

teamMembers.name: Austin Eidson

icp.companyStage: Series A to Series D product organizations (20-200 employees)

connectCriteria: Owns roadmap or product delivery outcomes
Mentions shipping velocity or team capacity
Posts about user research or retention
Recently announced a new product line
realQuotes: Our biggest struggle is aligning the product and engineering backlogs.
I need proof that a team can ship in weeks, not quarters.
Retention fell because we didn't onboard users fast enough.
We have more ideas than execution capacity.
Every roadmap cut is political.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], loved your point about roadmap trade-offs. We help product teams ship focused experiments quickly—curious how you're tackling velocity vs. quality right now?
[Name], saw you mention onboarding drop-off. We've helped teams fix that by shipping tight onboarding flows in weeks. Want to compare notes?
conversationStarters.whenToUse: After they mention retention or onboarding

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], big fan of your product insights. We work with product leads who need an extra embedded squad to hit launch dates—happy to share how it works.

contentPillars.title: Experiment Velocity
examples: How to ship a 2-week product experiment
The cost of delayed roadmap bets

engagementBoosters: Engage with product lead posts before sharing your own
Use metrics in hooks (e.g., 18% retention lift)
Ask for opinions on roadmap trade-offs

examplePosts.title: Roadmap Ruthlessness
examplePosts.content:
Last quarter we had 47 feature requests on the roadmap.

We shipped 6.

Here's how we chose them:
• Mapped each to a retention or expansion metric
• Killed anything that didn't move the needle in 30 days
• Forced every PM to answer: "What happens if we DON'T build this?"

The result?
→ 18% improvement in 30-day retention
→ Team morale went UP (less context-switching)
→ Engineering actually finished what they started

The hardest product skill isn't prioritization.

It's saying no to good ideas.

What's your framework for killing features?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Specific numbers (47 to 6) create curiosity. Shows a clear framework others can steal. Metrics prove the approach worked. Question invites PMs to share their own methods.

examplePosts.title: Onboarding Teardown
examplePosts.content:
We were losing 40% of new users before they reached their "aha moment."

The fix wasn't a redesign. It was a stopwatch.

We timed every step of onboarding:
• Sign-up to first action: 4 minutes (too long)
• First action to value: 7 minutes (way too long)
• Total time to "aha": 11 minutes

We cut it to 3 minutes by:
1. Removing 2 setup screens
2. Pre-populating sample data
3. Adding a single guided tooltip

No new features. No engineering sprint. A 2-week scoped project.

Retention jumped 23%.

Stop building new features. Fix the first 5 minutes.
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Opens with a painful metric (40% drop-off). Simple, replicable framework (just time it). Concrete result (23% lift) with minimal effort. Ends with a punchy, shareable takeaway.

examplePosts.title: Product vs. Engineering Hot Take
examplePosts.content:
Hot take: Most product-engineering friction isn't about priorities.

It's about translation.

Product says: "We need to improve activation."
Engineering hears: "Rebuild the onboarding flow."

Product says: "Users are churning."
Engineering hears: "Build 10 new features."

Product says: "We need to move faster."
Engineering hears: "Cut corners."

The fix isn't better roadmaps. It's better specs.

One page. Clear outcome. Measurable success criteria. Definition of done.

Do this and watch shipping velocity double.

Agree or disagree?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Reframes a common conflict in a new way. The parallel structure (says/hears) is instantly relatable. Simple solution that both PMs and engineers can rally behind. 'Agree or disagree' drives comment debate.

teamMembers.name: Cyril Jones
connectCriteria: Owns systems for sales or revenue operations
Talks about pipeline or CRM tooling
realQuotes: We spend too much time cleaning CRM data.
Forecasting feels like educated guessing.
We need automation but don't have bandwidth.
Sales enablement tools aren't integrated.
Our handoffs are leaking revenue.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], your post about CRM hygiene hit home. We build scoped automation that clears manual cleanup—how are you approaching it this quarter?
[Name], saw your take on forecasting. We've helped RevOps teams build lightweight data workflows fast—want to swap notes?
Hey [Name], we work with RevOps leaders to streamline sales tooling without a full rebuild. Happy to share a quick playbook if helpful.

contentPillars.title: Automation Wins
examples: Time saved by cleaning CRM workflows

examplePosts.title: CRM Horror Story
examplePosts.content:
I audited a $40M ARR company's CRM last month.

What I found:
• 34% of deals had no next step logged
• 22% of contacts had invalid emails
• Pipeline was overstated by $2.1M
• 3 reps were forecasting the same account
• "Closed Lost" reasons were blank on 61% of records

Their forecast accuracy? 38%.

They didn't need a new CRM.
They didn't need a new sales methodology.
They needed 3 automations and 2 required fields.

We scoped it. Fixed it in 3 weeks.

Forecast accuracy is now 79%.

Your CRM isn't broken. Your data hygiene is.

What's the worst CRM data you've ever seen?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Shocking specifics (34%, $2.1M overstatement) grab attention. The simple fix (3 automations, 2 fields) is surprisingly actionable. Before/after metric proves ROI. Question invites horror story sharing in comments.

examplePosts.title: RevOps Stack Debate
examplePosts.content:
Unpopular RevOps opinion:

You don't need 12 tools in your revenue stack.

You need 4:
1. CRM (your single source of truth)
2. Engagement platform (sequences + tracking)
3. BI layer (dashboards + forecasting)
4. Integration glue (sync everything)

Every tool beyond these 4 should justify its existence quarterly.

I've seen teams with 15+ tools that can't answer: "What's our real pipeline?"

And I've seen teams with 4 tools that forecast within 5%.

The difference isn't the stack. It's the data flow.

What's in your RevOps stack right now? (Be honest.)
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Contrarian take on tool bloat resonates with budget-conscious ops leaders. Clear, simple framework (just 4 tools) is easy to remember. 'Be honest' creates vulnerability and drives comments. Pure engagement play that builds authority.

examplePosts.title: Handoff Revenue Leak
examplePosts.content:
The most expensive moment in your revenue cycle isn't closing.

It's the handoff.

Sales to CS. CS to Support. Support back to Sales for expansion.

We mapped one client's handoffs and found:
→ Average 4.2 days between close and CS intro
→ 37% of expansion signals never reached sales
→ NPS dropped 18 points in the first 2 weeks post-sale

The fix was a scoped automation project:
• Auto-trigger CS intro at contract signature
• Usage alerts routed to expansion reps
• Health score visible across all teams

Time to build: 4 weeks.
Revenue recovered: $380K in expansion pipeline (first quarter).

Where are your handoffs leaking?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Reframes a common problem (handoffs) as a revenue problem. Specific data points make it feel like a real audit. Clear ROI ($380K) justifies the investment. Targets multiple buyer personas (Sales, CS, RevOps) for broad reach.

teamMembers.name: Dom Paulk
realQuotes: Our CPL is rising and we need creative quickly.
Attribution is messy across channels.
We can't scale content without burning out the team.
We need a site refresh before next quarter.
Events are great, but follow-up is weak.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], your CPL comment resonated. We help marketing teams ship fast CRO experiments—how are you tackling performance dips right now?
[Name], saw your point on attribution chaos. We've helped teams build clearer reporting without a full rebuild—want a quick rundown?
Hey [Name], we partner with demand gen leads to scale content ops via embedded teams. Happy to share examples if useful.

contentPillars.title: Performance Experiments
examples: CRO test ideas for SaaS landing pages

contentPillars.title: Content Systems
examples: How to repurpose one webinar into 6 assets

contentPillars.title: Growth Ops
examples: Marketing ops fixes that save time

engagementBoosters: Ask what conversion blockers people see

examplePosts.title: Content Repurposing Framework
examplePosts.content:
We turned 1 webinar into 23 pieces of content last month.

Here's the exact breakdown:

From a 45-minute webinar:
→ 1 full blog post (from the transcript)
→ 3 short blog posts (one per key theme)
→ 1 gated PDF (slides + key takeaways)
→ 8 LinkedIn posts (quotes + hot takes from speakers)
→ 4 email nurture touches
→ 3 short video clips (under 90 seconds each)
→ 2 infographics
→ 1 podcast episode (audio-only version)

Total time: 12 hours of work across the team.
Cost per asset: ~$47.

Stop creating content from scratch every time.

Start with one anchor and multiply.

What's your best content repurposing hack?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Extremely specific and actionable (23 pieces, exact list). The cost-per-asset math makes it tangible for budget holders. Framework is immediately stealable. Question drives comments from content marketers sharing tips.

examplePosts.title: Attribution Reality Check
examplePosts.content:
Honest question for B2B marketers:

When's the last time your attribution model actually changed a decision?

I'll go first.

We spent 6 months building a multi-touch attribution model. Beautiful dashboards. Every touchpoint tracked.

Then I asked our CMO: "Has this changed how you allocate budget?"

Silence.

The truth: 80% of attribution work is theater.

What actually drives decisions:
• Ask new customers "how did you hear about us?" (self-reported)
• Track 3 metrics, not 30 (CPL, pipeline influence, CAC payback)
• Run simple A/B holdout tests on channels

Perfect attribution is a myth.
Directionally correct attribution is a weapon.

Am I wrong?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Vulnerable admission (we wasted 6 months) builds trust. Challenges a sacred cow in marketing (attribution). Simple alternative framework is refreshing. 'Am I wrong?' invites healthy debate.

examplePosts.title: CPL Crisis Playbook
examplePosts.content:
Our CPL jumped 40% in one quarter.

Here's the 3-week sprint that brought it back down:

Week 1 - Diagnose:
• Audited every ad set (found 3 audiences with 60%+ overlap)
• Checked landing pages (one had a 12-second load time)
• Reviewed lead scoring (MQL definition had drifted)

Week 2 - Fix:
• Consolidated overlapping audiences
• Rebuilt the top landing page (load time: 2.1 seconds)
• Tightened MQL criteria with sales alignment

Week 3 - Test:
• Launched 4 new ad variations
• A/B tested two landing page layouts
• Set up weekly CPL alerts

Result: CPL dropped 31% and pipeline quality improved.

The lesson: Rising CPL is usually 3-4 small problems, not 1 big one.

What's your go-to move when CPL spikes?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Timely pain point (rising CPL affects every demand gen leader). Week-by-week structure is easy to follow and steal. Specific fixes are actionable, not theoretical. Lead-generating because it signals expertise in paid performance.

teamMembers.name: Jerrod Tracy
engageCriteria: No current hiring or scaling needs
realQuotes: We have too much work and not enough senior engineers.
Our backlog is full of tech debt tickets.
Hiring is taking 4+ months per role.
We need to ship fast without breaking production.
Our roadmap is blocked by infrastructure work.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], your post about hiring lead time is real. We embed senior engineers quickly so teams can ship while hiring—how are you balancing that?
[Name], saw your comments on tech debt. We've helped teams knock out debt with scoped projects in parallel—want to compare approaches?
Hey [Name], we support engineering leaders with embedded squads during peak roadmap pushes. Happy to share what that looks like.

contentPillars.title: Capacity Relief
examples: How to ship without burning out engineers

contentPillars.title: Technical Strategy
examples: Managing tech debt with scoped sprints

contentPillars.title: Recruiting Reality
examples: Why hiring takes longer than planned

examplePosts.title: Tech Debt Accounting
examplePosts.content:
Your tech debt has a dollar value. Have you calculated it?

Here's a simple framework I use:

For every tech debt item, estimate:
• How many hours/week it costs in workarounds
• How many incidents it causes per month
• How much it slows new feature delivery

Example from a client:
→ Legacy auth system: 6 hrs/week in workarounds
→ 3 incidents/month (avg 2 hrs each to resolve)
→ Every new feature takes 30% longer because of it

Annualized cost: ~$180K in lost engineering productivity.

The fix was a 6-week scoped project. Cost: $45K.

ROI: 4x in year one.

Tech debt isn't a "someday" problem. It's a math problem.

Stop calling it debt. Start calling it what it is: a recurring expense.

How do you prioritize tech debt on your team?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Reframes tech debt in business terms (dollars, not story points). The specific example with real numbers makes it concrete. 4x ROI makes the case for action. Engineering leaders share it because it helps them justify debt sprints to leadership.

examplePosts.title: Hiring Timeline Reality
examplePosts.content:
I tracked every engineering hire we made last year.

Average time from "we need someone" to "they're productive":

• Writing the job description: 1-2 weeks
• Sourcing candidates: 3-4 weeks
• Interview loops: 2-3 weeks
• Offer + negotiation: 1-2 weeks
• Notice period: 2-4 weeks
• Onboarding to productive: 4-8 weeks

Best case: 13 weeks.
Realistic case: 20+ weeks.

That's 5 months before they ship meaningful code.

Meanwhile, the roadmap doesn't pause.
Customers don't wait.
Competitors don't slow down.

This is why smart engineering leaders run a dual strategy:
1. Hire for the long term
2. Embed for the short term

Both. Not either/or.

What's your average time-to-productive for new hires?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Real data from actual tracking is more credible than estimates. The timeline adds up in a way that's undeniable. Positions embedded teams as complementary (not competitive) to hiring. Question drives engagement from engineering managers comparing notes.

examplePosts.title: Developer Productivity Hot Take
examplePosts.content:
Controversial opinion: Most developer productivity tools are solving the wrong problem.

The #1 thing slowing your engineers down isn't:
❌ Their IDE
❌ Their CI/CD pipeline
❌ Their code review process
❌ Their standup format

It's context switching.

The average engineer at a scaling startup is on:
• 2-3 projects simultaneously
• 4-6 Slack channels actively pinging
• 3+ meetings per day
• 1-2 on-call rotations per month

You don't need better tools. You need fewer priorities.

One engineer on one project ships 3x faster than one engineer split across three projects.

This isn't opinion. It's math.

But it requires something most leaders won't do: say no to stakeholders.

What's the biggest productivity killer on your team?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Challenges the popular narrative around developer tooling. Specific numbers (2-3 projects, 4-6 channels) are instantly recognizable. The '3x faster' claim is bold but defensible. Drives debate between engineering leaders about focus vs. flexibility.

teamMembers.name: Jesse Kinzer
realQuotes: Churn is creeping up and we need to act fast.
Onboarding takes too long for new customers.
We lack a single source of truth for health scores.
Support is overwhelmed during launches.
We need better expansion plays.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], your churn comment hit home. We help CS teams ship onboarding improvements fast—how are you tackling retention right now?
[Name], saw your post about health scores. We've helped teams build lightweight dashboards quickly—want to see an example?
Hey [Name], we partner with CS leaders to automate support workflows without disrupting teams. Happy to share ideas.

examplePosts.title: Churn Autopsy
examplePosts.content:
We lost 23 accounts last quarter.

So I did a churn autopsy on every single one.

The results surprised me:

• 4% left because of price
• 11% left for a competitor
• 31% left because of poor onboarding
• 54% left because they never adopted a key feature

Read that again: 85% of churn was preventable.

Not with discounts. Not with better features.

With better customer success in the first 30 days.

Here's what we changed:
1. Added a day-3 check-in call (not email, a call)
2. Built an adoption checklist with 5 milestones
3. Set up automated alerts when usage drops below threshold

90-day retention improved by 19%.

Churn is rarely about your product.
It's about the experience around your product.

What's driving churn at your company?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Real data from actual churn analysis builds credibility. The '85% preventable' stat is attention-grabbing and shareable. Simple 3-step fix is actionable. Reframes churn as a CS problem, not a product problem, which resonates with CS leaders.

examplePosts.title: Health Score Reality
examplePosts.content:
Hot take: Most customer health scores are vanity metrics.

I've seen health score dashboards that:
• Show 90% of accounts as "green"
• Never predicted a single churn
• Don't trigger any action from CSMs
• Haven't been recalibrated in 18 months

If your health score doesn't change how your team behaves, it's decoration.

Here's what a useful health score actually needs:

1. Leading indicators (login frequency, feature adoption, support tickets)
2. A threshold that triggers action (not just a color change)
3. Recalibration every quarter against actual churn data
4. CSM accountability tied to score changes

We rebuilt a client's health scoring in a 4-week scoped project.

Before: Health scores predicted churn 12% of the time.
After: 67% prediction accuracy.

The dashboard isn't the hard part. The scoring model is.

What signals are in your health score?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Calls out a common problem (useless health scores) that CS ops people recognize instantly. Provides a clear 4-part framework. Before/after stat (12% to 67%) proves the point. Question invites CS leaders to share their own approaches.

examplePosts.title: Onboarding Speed Wins
examplePosts.content:
The fastest way to reduce churn doesn't cost anything.

Speed up onboarding.

We measured time-to-value across 200 customers:

• Customers who reached value in < 7 days: 94% retention at 12 months
• Customers who reached value in 7-30 days: 71% retention
• Customers who took 30+ days: 43% retention

The gap is massive. And it's not about features.

Here's what we did to compress time-to-value:

1. Defined "value" as one specific action (not 10)
2. Removed 4 optional setup steps that confused users
3. Assigned a CSM on day 1 (not day 14)
4. Built a 3-email drip focused only on that one action

Result: Average time-to-value dropped from 18 days to 5 days.

Every day between signup and "aha" is a day they might leave.

How long does it take your customers to reach value?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Hard data (retention rates by time-to-value) is extremely compelling for CS leaders. The advice is counterintuitive (simplify, don't add). Specific result (18 days to 5) proves it works. High lead count because it signals expertise in the exact problem CS teams are solving.

teamMembers.name: Ryan Doss
realQuotes: We need clearer visibility into capacity.
Margins are compressed and we need fixes.
Manual processes slow us down.
Forecasting is reactive instead of proactive.
Hiring is ahead of process maturity.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], your post about margin pressure resonates. We help ops teams streamline workflows fast—how are you addressing it this quarter?
[Name], saw your note on forecasting challenges. We've helped teams build automated reporting quickly—want to see a sample?
Hey [Name], we partner with operators to build scalable processes without slowing growth. Happy to share a playbook.

examplePosts.title: Spreadsheet to System
examplePosts.content:
Every scaling company has "the spreadsheet."

You know the one.

It started as a quick tracker. Now it:
• Has 47 tabs
• Takes 3 hours to update weekly
• Breaks when someone sorts wrong
• Is the single source of truth for capacity planning
• Only one person fully understands it

We see this in nearly every ops team we work with.

Here's the progression that actually works:

Phase 1: Identify the 3 spreadsheets that hurt the most
Phase 2: Build lightweight automation (not a full platform)
Phase 3: Create a dashboard that updates itself

We did this for a 90-person services company.

Before: 14 hours/week on manual reporting.
After: 2 hours/week, with better accuracy.

ROI in 6 weeks.

You don't need a $200K platform. You need a scoped project.

What's YOUR "spreadsheet from hell"?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Universal pain point (every company has that spreadsheet). Humor and specificity (47 tabs, breaks when sorted) make it relatable. Phased approach feels achievable, not overwhelming. ROI timeline (6 weeks) appeals to budget-conscious operators.

examplePosts.title: Margin Math Breakdown
examplePosts.content:
Most services businesses know their margins.

Few know where they're leaking.

We ran a margin audit for a 60-person company. Here's what we found:

• 18% of billable capacity was lost to internal meetings
• Scope creep on 40% of projects (untracked)
• Utilization was reported at 78% but was actually 61%
• Invoicing lag averaged 22 days (cash flow impact: $340K/year)

The margin they reported: 32%.
The real margin: 19%.

The fix wasn't layoffs or price increases.

It was process:
1. Time tracking enforcement (simple tool, not complex)
2. Scope change approval workflow
3. Automated invoicing triggers
4. Weekly utilization dashboard

Margins recovered to 29% in one quarter.

What's your biggest hidden margin leak?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: The gap between reported and real margin (32% vs 19%) is a wake-up call. Specific, fixable problems make it feel solvable. No-drama solutions (process, not layoffs) resonate with operators. Drives comments from leaders sharing their own margin discoveries.

examplePosts.title: Forecasting Hot Take
examplePosts.content:
Unpopular opinion: Your financial forecast is fiction.

And that's okay—if you know which parts are fiction.

Most forecasts I review have the same problems:
❌ Revenue assumes every pipeline deal closes
❌ Headcount plan assumes everyone starts on day 1
❌ Costs don't include the "surprises" that happen every quarter
❌ Growth rate is copy-pasted from the board deck

Here's a better approach:

✅ Forecast 3 scenarios (base, bull, bear)
✅ Weight pipeline by stage probability
✅ Add a 15% buffer for unplanned costs
✅ Update monthly, not quarterly
✅ Track forecast accuracy and improve the model

The goal isn't a perfect prediction.

It's a useful decision-making tool.

A forecast that's directionally right and updated often beats a detailed forecast that's updated quarterly.

How often does your team update its forecast?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: 'Your forecast is fiction' is a bold hook that stops the scroll. The common problems list hits home for every ops/finance leader. Practical framework (3 scenarios, 15% buffer) is immediately useful. Drives engagement from finance-adjacent leaders who have strong opinions.

teamMembers.name: Scott Blevins
realQuotes: Partner enablement always lags behind.
We need faster integration timelines.
Co-marketing isn't driving pipeline yet.
We have too many partners and no prioritization.
We need a cleaner partner onboarding flow.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], your post about partner enablement is spot on. We've helped teams build partner onboarding flows quickly—how are you tackling it?
[Name], saw your note on integration timelines. We support teams with scoped dev sprints to speed them up—want to swap ideas?
Hey [Name], we help partnerships teams operationalize co-marketing with embedded support. Happy to share a framework.

examplePosts.title: Partner Prioritization Matrix
examplePosts.content:
We had 45 partners on paper.

3 were driving 80% of our partner-sourced pipeline.

The other 42? Mostly logos on a webpage.

Here's the prioritization matrix we built to fix this:

Tier 1 (Invest): Shared ICP + active co-selling + integration live
→ Dedicated partner manager, co-marketing budget, quarterly business reviews

Tier 2 (Enable): Shared ICP + willing to co-sell + integration planned
→ Self-serve enablement, monthly check-in, co-marketing templates

Tier 3 (Monitor): Loose ICP overlap + no active co-selling
→ Quarterly newsletter, annual review, no dedicated resources

Tier 4 (Sunset): No pipeline contribution in 12 months
→ Offboard gracefully

Result after 6 months:
• Partner-sourced pipeline up 34%
• Team focused on 8 partners instead of 45
• Co-sell win rate improved from 18% to 31%

More partners doesn't mean more pipeline.

Better partners does.

How do you tier your partners?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: The 45-to-3 stat is immediately attention-grabbing. The tiered framework is practical and stealable. Results are specific and compelling. Partnership leaders share because it validates what they already suspect.

examplePosts.title: Integration Timeline Rant
examplePosts.content:
The #1 partnership killer isn't strategy.

It's integration timelines.

I've seen this pattern dozens of times:

Month 1: "We should integrate!"
Month 2: "Let's get the PMs aligned."
Month 3: "Engineering will scope it next sprint."
Month 4: "It's in the backlog."
Month 5: "It got deprioritized."
Month 6: "Let's revisit next quarter."

Meanwhile, the partner champion leaves.
The momentum dies.
The pipeline projection gets zeroed out.

The fix: Treat integrations like scoped projects.

• Dedicated team (not borrowed from product backlog)
• Fixed timeline (4-6 weeks, not "when we get to it")
• Ship an MVP integration first (sync 2 objects, not 20)

We helped a client ship 3 partner integrations in 8 weeks using this approach.

Pipeline from those integrations in Q1: $420K.

What's your integration backlog look like?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: The month-by-month timeline is painfully accurate for partnership people. Positions the problem as solvable with a clear approach. Revenue number ($420K) makes the business case. Drives comments from frustrated BD leaders sharing similar stories.

examplePosts.title: Co-Marketing Playbook
examplePosts.content:
We ran 12 co-marketing campaigns with partners last year.

4 drove pipeline. 8 were duds.

Here's what separated the winners:

What flopped:
• Co-branded whitepapers nobody downloaded
• Joint webinars with no promotion plan
• "Partner spotlight" blog posts
• Social media cross-posts

What worked:
• Joint customer case study with both logos
• Co-hosted workshop with hands-on demo
• Shared SDR outreach to overlapping accounts
• Integration launch event with live walkthrough

The pattern: Co-marketing works when both sides bring their audience AND there's a clear next step.

A PDF isn't a next step.
A live demo is.

What's your best-performing co-marketing play?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Honest admission of failure (8 out of 12 flopped) builds trust. Clear contrast between what works and what doesn't. Practical insight (the pattern) is memorable. Low engagement numbers reflect the niche audience but high relevance drives quality comments.

teamMembers.name: Sonya Mead

icp.title: The Early-Stage Builder
icp.companyStage: Pre-seed to Series A startups (2-25 employees)

realQuotes: We need an MVP in weeks, not months.
Customer interviews keep changing the roadmap.
Fundraising depends on getting product traction.
We're stuck hiring the first engineers.
We need to validate fast before running out of runway.

conversationStarters.template: Hey [Name], saw your MVP timeline post. We help founders ship fast without full-time hires—how are you approaching build vs. hire?
[Name], loved your note on customer discovery. We've helped teams iterate quickly with scoped sprints—want to compare notes?
Hey [Name], we partner with early-stage founders to get MVPs live quickly. Happy to share what that looks like.

contentPillars.title: MVP Momentum
examples: How to ship an MVP in 6 weeks

examplePosts.title: Customer Discovery Confession
examplePosts.content:
I talked to 40 potential customers before writing a single line of code.

Here's what I learned:

• The problem I wanted to solve wasn't their top 3 pain
• The feature I was most excited about? Nobody asked for it
• Their willingness to pay was 2x higher than I assumed
• The buyer wasn't who I thought (it was ops, not engineering)

3 of those 40 conversations turned into design partners.

2 of those 3 are now paying customers.

The MVP we built looked nothing like my original vision. And that's exactly the point.

Customer discovery isn't a phase you complete.
It's a muscle you build.

Most founders skip this because building feels more productive than listening.

It's not.

How many customer conversations did you have before building?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Personal vulnerability (my idea was wrong) builds authenticity. Specific surprising outcomes (buyer was ops, not engineering) create genuine insight. The 40-to-3-to-2 funnel is a realistic conversion path. Question invites founders to reflect honestly.

examplePosts.title: MVP Scoping Framework
examplePosts.content:
Every founder I talk to wants to build too much for their MVP.

Here's the scoping conversation I have every time:

Me: "What's the one thing a user MUST be able to do?"
Founder: "Well, they need to..."
(lists 12 features)

Me: "Okay. If they could only do ONE thing, what is it?"
Founder: "...upload data and see a dashboard."

Me: "Great. That's your MVP."

Everything else is V2.

The framework:

1. Define the ONE core action
2. Build the shortest path to that action
3. Make it work (not pretty, not perfect)
4. Put it in front of 5 real users
5. Watch what they do (not what they say)

We've used this to help founders go from idea to live product in 4-6 weeks.

The hardest part isn't building.
It's resisting the urge to build more.

What's the ONE thing your MVP needs to do?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: The dialogue format is engaging and feels like a real conversation. The framework is dead simple (5 steps). The insight (founders always list 12 features) is universally true. High lead count because it demonstrates scoping expertise that founders need.

examplePosts.title: Fundraising vs Building Tension
examplePosts.content:
The biggest lie in startups:

"We'll build after we raise."

Here's what actually happens:

• Investors want to see traction before they invest
• You need product to show traction
• You think you need money to build product
• So you spend 6 months fundraising with a pitch deck
• Meanwhile, the founder who just shipped is closing their round

The loop is broken by building.

Not by raising.

3 things that have worked for founders I've helped:

1. Ship a crappy V1 in 4-6 weeks (not 6 months)
2. Get 5-10 users (not 1,000)
3. Show up to investor meetings with usage data (not projections)

One founder went from "can't get meetings" to "oversubscribed round" in 8 weeks.

The difference? A live product with 8 paying users.

Investors don't fund ideas. They fund momentum.

Are you building or fundraising right now?
examplePosts.whyItWorked: Challenges a deeply held assumption (raise then build). The circular logic breakdown is eye-opening. Real example (8 weeks, 8 paying users, oversubscribed) is inspiring and specific. Binary question at end (building or fundraising?) drives self-reflection and comments.
